awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Slick Yet Stuck? Using Adhesion to Expose the Conditions of the Buried Cartilage Interface
awd_abstract_narration:
Remarkable adhesive mechanisms have evolved across the animal kingdom to help jumping spiders stick a landing, octopi catch prey, geckos locomote on vertical surfaces, and clingfish grip slippery, bio-fouled rocks. In each of these distinct and well-studied cases, there were strong connections between adhesion and survival to drive the evolutionary process. This research team has recently discovered that cartilage, a material well-known for exceptionally low adhesive friction, generates exceptionally strong adhesive stresses -- comparable to those of the gecko, octopus, and clingfish. This finding is paradoxical, because friction and adhesion are fundamentally linked. Additionally, unlike other natural examples of strong adhesion, there is no obvious evolutionary pressure for strong joint adhesion. The fact that cartilage simultaneously exhibits both "super-lubricity" and "super-adhesion" violates long-standing assumptions about cartilage lubrication while exposing critical clues about the unusual underlying mechanics. This EArly-Concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project seeks to resolve this "cartilage lubrication-adhesion" paradox.  The results will: (1) clarify how tensile forces are generated in the joint and what that implies about joint lubrication; (2) provide original insights into bio-adhesion while exposing new directions for bio-inspiration and materials discovery; (3) lend insight into the causes and consequences of "joint cracking", a common, clinically important, and poorly understood phenomenon.  If the understanding of cartilage functional mechanics are condensed into a single framework, it will inform substantially improved strategies to protect, treat, or replace compromised joints.

The project will use novel interfacial tension measurements to quantify interfacial permeability, experimentally separate the contributions from adhesion (seen in the gecko) and suction (seen in the clingfish) mechanisms, and systematically assess the intersection between cartilage friction and adhesion across length scales.  Using micro force microscopy, beam displacements from normal and friction forces will be quantified on an experimental indenter.  Cartilage samples (osteochondral cores) will be obtained from bovine joints.  Three aims have been developed.  The first will isolate the effect of exudation on adhesion, suction, and interfacial gaps by varying the dwell time prior to pull-off to systematically vary interstitial fluid loss.  The second aim will isolate and quantify adhesive forces by eliminating the contribution of suction, using quasistatic rates for the pull-off tests.  The third aim will quantify the interfacial properties (e.g. sliding friction, effective contact modulus, equilibrium modulus, and fluid load fraction) across length scales by using varying probe radii, which will have varying effects on suction forces (dependent on radius) and adhesion forces (independent of radius).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Remarkable adhesive mechanisms have evolved across the animal kingdom to help jumping spiders stick a landing, octopi catch prey, geckos locomote on vertical surfaces, and clingfish grip slick bio-fouled rocks. In each of these distinct and well-studied cases, there are known connections between adhesion and survival to drive the evolutionary process. We have recently discovered that cartilage, a material well-known for exceptionally low adhesive friction, generates exceptionally strong adhesion and tensile stresses rivaling those of the gecko, octopus, and clingfish. This finding is paradoxical because friction and adhesion are fundamentally linked. Additionally, unlike other natural examples of strong adhesion, there is no obvious evolutionary pressure for strong joint adhesion. The fact that cartilage simultaneously exhibits both ‘super-lubricity’ and ‘super-adhesion’ violates long-standing assumptions about cartilage lubrication while exposing critical clues about the underlying mechanics. 

This project aimed to resolve this cartilage lubrication-adhesion paradox. It used novel interfacial tension measurements to quantify interfacial permeability, experimentally separate the contributions from adhesion (e.g. that of the gecko) and suction (e.g. that of the clingfish), and systematically assess the intersection between cartilage friction and adhesion across length scales. The first aim isolated the effects of tissue hydration and fluid loss on adhesion and suction. The results of these experiments show that the interfacial tension developed between cartilage and other surfaces during pulloff is dominated by hydrodynamic forces (i.e. suction), which supported tensile stresses on the order 100 kPa (~1 atm). The measured power law relationship between force and distance suggests that these forces are associated with interstitial rather than interfacial flows, and the permeability was greater than but on the order of the permeability of the tissue itself. Contrary to the conventional wisdom that unloading exposes surfaces and facilitates surface rehydration following load carrying, these results imply that the contact interface remains highly impermeable even when pulled in tension. This observation explains why joints crack and why extraordinarily loads are required to distract large joints like the hip clinically.

The second aim sought to isolate and quantify the component of tension attributable to adhesion, which is due to intermolecular forces between contacting surfaces. Interestingly, we were unable to detect any adhesion, even after allowing for sufficient exudation to yield large friction coefficients. This observation is contrary to the expectation that friction increases with exudation due to adhesive interactions from larger areas of intimate contact. Instead, this observation is consistent with more recent suggestions that increased friction simply reflects a decreasing penetration length to accommodate fluid shear.  

The third aim sought to quantify the effects of length scale, specifically large length scales. In large cartilage-on-flat experiments tensile forces increased but tensile stresses decreased. Additionally, in-situ observation of the contact revealed that the contact area expanded and shrank much more quickly during exudation and recovery than did sample thickness via bulk fluid loss and recovery. These results indicate that the contact interface is more permeable than the tissue and equilibrates far more quickly than the bulk tissue. We attribute the increase in interfacial permeability to the presence of larger scale topography/waviness/form error in larger areas of contact. This aim demonstrates that time constants increase more quickly than theory would suggest with increased size scale and that friction, which is sensitive to interfacial hydration, increases and decreases more quickly than expected during fluid loss and recovery processes, respectively, at the joint scale.    


Last Modified: 04/15/2023
Modified by: David L Burris
